sn22.151:1.2: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what,
sn22.151:1.3: does someone regard things like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn22.151:1.4: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”
sn22.151:1.5: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form …
sn22.151:1.6: When consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness,
sn22.151:1.7: someone regards it like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’
sn22.151:1.11: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would you regard it like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn22.151:1.18: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would you regard it like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn22.151:1.21: They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’”
